source: CASA 2007 Attitudes on Substance Abuse Survey, August 2007
conducted_by: National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University
sample: National adult parents of teenagers (age 12-17) with oversamples of African Americans and Hispanics
question: Have you ever seen students smoking cigarettes on the grounds of your teen's school? (If Yes, ask:)Is smoking explicitly allowed, or is it tolerated, or does it happen despite the best efforts of the school administrators?
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, April 27 - May 13, 2007 and based on     550 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult parents of teenagers (age 12-17) with oversamples of African Americans and Hispanics. Interviews were conducted by QEV Analytics.  A parallel survey of 1297 teens age 12-17 was conducted.  All of the 562 interviews with parents were conducted in households where the parents gave consent for their teen to be interviewed even though the teen interview may not have been completed.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult parent of teens age 12-17 sample. [USCASA.07DRUGAP.R36] (View Citation)
Topics: EDUCATION HEALTH YOUTH
Formal Citation

question: Do you smoke a pipe or cigars or use chewing tobacco?
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
Harris Interactive, April 11 - April 18, 2011 and based on   1,987 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 1010 respondents were interviewed by telephone and 977 were interviewed online. The interviews conducted by telephone included a nationwide cross section of adults with landlines in their households.  The interviews conducted online included a nationwide sample who have agreed to take part in Harris Interactive surveys and who indicated not having a landline (i.e., cell phone only), or using their cell phone for almost all of their calls (cell phone mostly), and thus were included to ensure representation of these groups that are lacking among a traditional RDD sample.  Telephone data only were adjusted to ensure appropriate representation on number of telephone/voice lines and number of adults in the household, and online data only were adjusted by propensity to be online to correct for attitudinal/behavioral differences between our panel and those who respond by phone.  Finally, for the combined telephone and online data, figures for age, sex, race/ethnicity, education, region, household income, and phone status (cell phone only, cell phone mostly, dual users, landline mostly, landline only) were adjusted as necessary to bring them in line with their actual proportions in the population.  Population proportions for demographic variables were acquired from the 2010 Current Population Survey, while phone status proportions were acquired from the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS). [USHARRIS.052511.R1] (View Citation)
Topics: HEALTH
Formal Citation
Harris Interactive. Harris Poll,
Apr, 2011 [survey question]. USHARRIS.052511.R1. Harris Interactive [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.

description:
Survey by Pew Research Center for the People & the Press.
Methodology: Conducted by Princeton Survey Research Associates International, January 5 - March 15, 2012 and based on   2,226 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. 1263 respondents were interviewed on a landline telephone, and 963 were interviewed on a cell phone, including 464 who had no landline telephone.  The analysis for this study is based on two telephone surveys.  The standard survey was conducted Jan. 4-8, 2012 among 1507 adults and utilized Pew Research's standard survey methodology.  The second survey, the high-effort survey, was conducted Jan. 5-Mar. 15, 2012 among 2226 adults and utilized additional methods to increase participation.  The report for this study compares the two surveys. [USPSRA.051512H.R28] (View Citation)

description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, March 9 - April 30, 2006 and based on     562 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult parents of teenagers (age 12-17) with oversamples of African Americans and Hispanics. Interviews were conducted by QEV Analytics.  A parallel survey of 1297 teens age 12-17 was conducted.  All of the 562 interviews with parents were conducted in households where the parents gave consent for their teen to be interviewed even though the teen interview may not have been completed. survey_by: Brown & Willamson Tobacco Corp., Lorillard Tobacco Corp.,
conducted_by: The Tarrance Group and KRC Research
topic: CONGRESS HEALTH TAXING REGULATION BUSINESS YOUTH
question: As you may know, Congress is now considering a bill that--according to supporters--would impose an additional one dollar and ten cents-a-pack tax on cigarettes, restrict advertising and marketing of cigarettes, and put an annual limit on the amount of money that tobacco companies would have to pay out each year to settle smoking related lawsuits. Supporters say that this tobacco bill would reduce teen smoking while also raising billions of dollars to improve children's health. Opponents say that it could drive tobacco companies out of business by giving them too little protection from lawsuits, while raising taxes, creating new government bureaucracies, and making cigarettes so expensive that a new black market would emerge. Based on this information, do you think that Congress should pass this bill, or not?

url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=smoking or tobacco&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Milken Family Foundation's Milken Exchange on Education Technology&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=1012&qstn_list=&qstnid=331463&qa_list=&qstn_id4=331463&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332557&archno=&keywordDisplay=
description:
Survey by Milken Family Foundation's Milken Exchange on Education Technology.
Methodology: Conducted by Peter D. Hart Research Associates, May 29 - May 31, 1997 and based on   1,012 telephone interviews. Sample: National registered voters (see note). This study included an oversample of 211 registered voters in California. Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult population. There also were separate surveys of 304 public school teachers and administrators and of 303 public school students grade 6-12. [USHART.97SCED.R22A] (View Citation)
Topics: SCIENCE EDUCATION SPENDING TAXING CONSUMER HEALTH
Formal Citation

May, 1997 [survey question]. USHART.97SCED.R22A. Peter D. Hart Research Associates [producer].

source: People, The Press & Politics Poll--New Political Landscapes, September 1994
question: (Now I'd like your opinion of some groups and organizations.)Would you say your overall opinion of... tobacco companies... is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable?
description:
Survey by Times Mirror.
Methodology: Conducted by Princeton Survey Research Associates, July 12 - July 25, 1994 and based on   3,800 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The main sample of 3800 included an oversample of 197 black adults. The results are weighted to be representative of the national adult population. The study included a separate supplemental sample of 1009 adults interviewed 7/13-7/27/94, and a re-interview of 1500 adults from the main sample 9/9-11/94. Both of these are shown separately. [USPSRA.092194.R24K] (View Citation)
Topics: RATINGS INFORMATION BUSINESS
Formal Citation
Times Mirror. People, The Press & Politics Poll--New Political Landscapes,
Jul, 1994 [survey question]. USPSRA.092194.R24K. Princeton Survey Research Associates [producer].

Center for Public Opinion Research.

source: CASA 2011 Attitudes on Substance Abuse Survey, August 2011
conducted_by: National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University
question: During the past 30 days, on how many days did you smoke or chew tobacco?...0 days, 1 day, 2 days, 3 days, 4-29 days, 30 days
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, March 27 - April 27, 2011 and based on     528 online interviews. Sample: National adult parents of teenagers (age 12-17). Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  A parallel survey of 1037 teenagers age 12-17 was conducted online March 27-April 27, 2011.  For all parents interviewed online a teen in the same household was also interviewed.  There was also a telephone survey of 1006 teenagers age 12-17 conducted March 29-May 9, 2101 with interviews conducted by QEV Analytics, which included trend items. [USCASA.11DRUGP.R29] (View Citation)

source: CASA 2008 Attitudes on Substance Abuse Survey, August 2008
conducted_by: National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University
question: Next, I am going to read to you some potentially negative influences your teen may be exposed to, either through the Internet or through movies, television and music.  Please tell me which one, if any, concerns you the most....Irresponsible sexual behavior, the use of drugs, cigarette smoking, irresponsible drinking, making criminal activity seem glamorous, making violence against other people seem glamorous
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, April 17 - June 3, 2008 and based on     312 telephone interviews. Sample: National adults parents of teenagers (age 12-17). Interviews were conducted by QEV Analytics.  A parallel survey of 1002 teenagers age 12-17 was conducted April 3-May 13, 2008.  For all parents interviews a teen in the same household was also interviewed. [USCASA.08DRUGAP.R13] (View Citation)
Topics: FAMILY SCIENCE CULTURE TELEVISION MOOD
Formal Citation
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University. CASA 2008 Attitudes on Substance Abuse Survey,
Apr, 2008 [survey question]. USCASA.08DRUGAP.R13. National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Irresponsible sexual behavior': ' 38%', 'The use of drugs': ' 14%', 'Cigarette smoking': '  2%', 'Irresponsible drinking': '  8%', 'Making criminal activity seem glamorous': ' 10%', 'Making violence against other people seem glamorous': ' 20%', 'None of these (Vol.)': '  5%', "Don't know/No response": '  3%'}

source: CASA 2007 Attitudes on Substance Abuse Survey, August 2007
conducted_by: National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University
sample: National adult parents of teenagers (age 12-17) with oversamples of African Americans and Hispanics
question: Next, I'm going to read to you some potentially negative influences your teen may be exposed to, either through the Internet or through movies, television and music.  Please tell me which one, if any, concerns you the most....Irresponsible sexual behavior, the use of drugs, cigarette smoking, irresponsible drinking, making criminal activity seem glamorous, making violence against other people seem glamorous
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, April 27 - May 13, 2007 and based on     550 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult parents of teenagers (age 12-17) with oversamples of African Americans and Hispanics. Interviews were conducted by QEV Analytics.  A parallel survey of 1297 teens age 12-17 was conducted.  All of the 562 interviews with parents were conducted in households where the parents gave consent for their teen to be interviewed even though the teen interview may not have been completed.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult parent of teens age 12-17 sample. [USCASA.07DRUGAP.R11] (View Citation)
Topics: FAMILY SCIENCE CULTURE TELEVISION MOOD
Formal Citation
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University. CASA 2007 Attitudes on Substance Abuse Survey,
Apr, 2007 [survey question]. USCASA.07DRUGAP.R11. National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Irresponsible sexual behavior': ' 33%', 'The use of drugs': ' 12%', 'Cigarette smoking': '  1%', 'Irresponsible drinking': '  7%', 'Making criminal activity seem glamorous': ' 13%', 'Making violence against other people seem glamorous': ' 23%', 'None of the above (Vol.)': '  8%', "Don't know/No response": '  3%'}

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, April 2014
question: On the next few screens, you'll see a series of statements about science and medicine. For each of them, please indicate how confident you are that the statement is correct....Smoking causes cancer...Extremely confident, very confident, somewhat confident, not too confident, not at all confident
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, March 20 - March 24, 2014 and based on   1,012 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.042114G.R01A] (View Citation)
Topics: INFORMATION HEALTH
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Mar, 2014 [survey question]. USAP.042114G.R01A. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement

Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Extremely confident': ' 59%', 'Very confident': ' 23%', 'Somewhat confident': ' 12%', 'Not too confident': '  4%', 'Not at all confident': '  1%', 'Refused/Not answered': '  2%'}

question: (You may have heard about a government operation under the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms known as 'Fast and Furious,' that was designed to track illegal gun sales and lead agents to gun cartel members so they could be arrested.  Yet instead of stopping illegal gun trafficking, the operation allowed thousands of guns to be smuggled to criminals in Mexico and one is believed to have been used to kill a US (United States)border agent.)Congress is investigating the government's 'Fast and Furious' operation.  Attorney General Eric Holder has refused to turn over certain requested documents related to 'Fast and Furious,' and now President Barack Obama has invoked executive privilege to keep from having to give those documents to Congress.  Do you think the president's use of executive privilege means the administration is hiding something or do you think Obama is using it to protect confidential information for a legitimate reason?

source: CASA National Addiction Belief and Attitude Survey, June 2012
conducted_by: National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University
question: Do you think public health insurance plans like Medicare or Medicaid that are paid for by the tax dollars of people like you should cover treatment for addiction to...tobacco or do you not think so? (If Yes, ask:)Do you think public health insurance plans should provide patients with as much treatment as they need for the addictions to...tobacco without limits or do you think there should be limits on addictions treatment such as 'X' number of physician visits or 'Y' number of days per year of hospital or other residential care?
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, October 21 - November 3, 2008 and based on   1,303 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. Interviews were conducted by Peter D. Hart Research Associates.  The national survey is part of the CASA "Addiction Medicine:  Closing the Gap Between Science and Practice Study."  There were also other surveys.  There were two statewide surveys of addiction treatment providers in New York state, a national panel of treatment providers, and an online survey of 1142 members of professional associations involved in addiction care.  Also there was an online survey of 360 individuals with a history of addiction who are managing the disease.  Funding was provided by The Annenberg Foundation, The Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund and The Franklin Mint, The New York Community Trust, and Adrian and Jessie Archbold Charitable Trust. [USCASA.12ADDICT.R14D] (View Citation)
Topics: MEDICINE HEALTH ELDERLY SPENDING
Formal Citation
National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University. CASA National Addiction Belief and Attitude Survey,
Oct, 2008 [survey question]. USCASA.12ADDICT.R14D. National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Yes, should cover treatment without limits': ' 21%', 'Yes, should cover treatment with limits on days': ' 30%', 'Not sure about limits': '  3%', 'No, should not cover treatment': ' 42%', 'Not sure': '  4%'}

source: Public Perceptions of the State Children's Health Insurance Program Survey, August 2007
question: (Now thinking about these two points of view in more detail.  I am going to read you some more specific reasons why some people support expansion of SCHIP (State Children's Insurance Program)and why some people oppose expansion of SCHIP.  For each set of reasons please tell me which point of view you agree with more.)...Opponents of expanding SCHIP say it costs too much.  At a time when Congressional spending is at an all time high, creating an enormous budget deficit by expanding SCHIP means billions of dollars in deficit spending.  Supporters of expanding SCHIP say that SCHIP is a proven, cost effective way to cover our kids.  An increase in the federal tobacco tax will help pay for children enrolled in SCHIP and cover four million more low-income uninsured children while also discouraging people, especially teens, from smoking.  Which point of view do you agree with more? (If Both, prompt:)I realize you said you agree with both points of view, but if you had to choose just one, which one point of view do you tend to agree with more?

source: Public Perceptions of the State Children's Health Insurance Program Survey, August 2007
topic: HEALTH YOUTH STATES CONGRESS TAXING MEDICINE SPENDING
question: Thinking again about the arguments you heard earlier in favor of Congress voting to expand SCHIP (State Children's Health Insurance Program), which one of the following reasons would you say is the most compelling argument to favor Congress voting to expand SCHIP to cover an additional four million uninsured children?...Children enrolled in SCHIP are able to see doctors when they are sick, get checkups, prescription medications and hospitalizations.  It can be paid for by a federal tobacco tax which will also discourage teens from smoking.  SCHIP covers six million kids whose parents work but cannot afford insurance on their own.  It is a proven, cost effective way to cover kids.   SCHIP has decreased the number of uninsured children by nearly 25%.  Three quarters of children enrolled in SCHIP were uninsured or on Medicaid before they joined.  SCHIP coverage is provided through private health insurance companies.

question: Which of the following statements comes closer to your point of view?...Statement A:  We should give the Food and Drug Administration the authority to regulate tobacco products because tobacco is exempt from the basic health protections that the FDA applies to other products.  Currently, the FDA can regulate a box of macaroni and cheese, but not a pack of cigarettes.  This bill will provide additional resources for the scientists and health professionals at the FDA to effectively regulate tobacco products without taking away from its other responsibilities.  Statement B:  We should not give the Food and Drug Administration the authority to regulate tobacco products because the FDA already has its hands full trying to regulate prescription drugs and other products.  Regulating tobacco would take time and resources away from the FDA's main job of approving potentially life saving medications. (If A/B, ask:)Do you feel that way strongly or not so strongly?

question: Which of the following statements comes closer to your point of view?...Statement A:  We should give the Food and Drug Administration the authority to regulate tobacco products and their marketing.  The tobacco companies spend more than $13 billion dollars every year marketing their deadly products, and much of that marketing directly impacts kids.  The marketing restrictions included in the bill will help prevent tobacco companies from addicting our children.  Statement B:  We should not give the Food and Drug Administration the authority to regulate tobacco products because the marketing restrictions included in the proposed bill would be an unconstitutional limitation on free speech and restrict the right of tobacco companies to market their products to adults who choose not to smoke. (If A/B, ask:)Do you feel that way strongly or not so strongly?

source: CASA 2002 Attitudes On Substance Abuse Survey, August 2002
conducted_by: National Center On Addiction And Substance Abuse At Columbia University
question: Let me read to you a list of five substances. Please put them in order from most harmful to least harmful. Here's the list--tobacco, marijuana, cocaine, alcohol, ecstasy. Which is the most harmful?
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
National Center On Addiction And Substance Abuse At Columbia University, December 27 - February 6, 2002 and based on     541 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult parents of teenagers. source: Alcohol And Treatment And Smoking and Youth Survey, July 2000
survey_by: Harvard School of Public Health, Robert Wood Johnson Foundation
topic: COURTS STATES BUSINESS HEALTH SPENDING EDUCATION YOUTH
question: As you may know, the states have settled their law suits with the tobacco industry to recover damages for the money the states have spent treating smoking related illness. Each state will receive millions of dollars over the next twenty-five years. I'm going to read you a list of some of the things that states may do with that money, As I read each one, please tell me if you think it should be a top priority for the use of that money, important but a lower priority, not an important priority, or not a priority at all for the use of that money? How about...to pay for educational programs to reduce tobacco use among young people?

question: (Now, I'm going to read you a list of some different things the President (Bill Clinton)and the new Congress might try to do in the next year.  As I read each one, tell me if you think it should be one of their top priorities, important but a lower priority, not too important, or should not be done.)What about this...passing anti-tobacco laws to reduce teen smoking?  Should this be one of their top priorities, important but a lower priority, not too important, or should this not be done?

source: American Viewpoint National Monitor Survey, July 1998
question: Which candidate would you be most likely to support for Congress? Candidate A's top priorities are to reduce the national debt, cut wasteful government spending, eliminate the inheritance tax, phase out the marriage penalty tax, and further reduce the capital gains tax from 20% to 15%. He also wants to find ways to address the youth smoking issue by targeting retailers who sell cigarettes to minors and better protect those enrolled in HMO's (Health Maintenance Organizations), but without creating federal bureaucracy and spending. Candidate B's top priorities are to put any budget surplus into Social Security, to greatly expand the role of the federal government in the youth smoking issue and to make major change in how HMO's operate including Patient's Bill of Rights which would allow those enrolled in HMO's to sue the HMO's. He does not believe that tax relief should be a priority this year.

source: American Viewpoint National Monitor Survey, June 1998
question: I am going to read you some paired statements of two candidates with differing views on the issues. Tell me if you would be more likely to vote for candidate A or candidate B for Congress. Candidate A's message consists of 4 points: Dedicating any surplus to saving Social Security first, passing a federal bill that deals with curbing underage smoking by increasing the taxes on cigarettes, cracking down on HMO's (Health Maintenance Organizations)by passing more stringent federal regulations and improving the quality of education by increasing federal spending and administering national standards to students in the 4th and 7th grades. Candidate B's message is: To use the budget surplus to save Social Security and lower taxes by providing a two percent tax credit to allow people to invest in voluntary private retirement accounts which would provide for financial security and peace of mind in the retirement years, to place a greater emphasis on curbing illegal drug usage among teenagers than on curbing teen smoking, and improving the quality of education through provision of school vouchers and opportunity scholarships and addressing juvenile violence in schools.
description:
Methodology: Conducted by
American Viewpoint, June 1 - June 7, 1998 and based on   1,000 telephone interviews. Sample: National registered voters.  [USAMVW.060998.R07] (View Citation)

question: I have a few more questions about recent health-related news stories. Again, if you're not sure of an answer, just say so and I'll go to the next question.... Last month (March, 1998), Republicans in Congress proposed using higher cigarette taxes to help individuals and businesses buy health insurance. As far as you know, which one of the following three ways do they propose to do this? Is it by using tobacco tax money...to expand Medicaid, the federal program that helps low-income people pay for health care, to pay for tax breaks to make it easier for individuals and businesses to afford health insurance, or to help individuals and businesses set up Medical Savings Accounts that can be used to pay future health care bills?

source: NBC News/Wall Street Journal Poll, September 1997
question: As you may know, the nation's biggest tobacco companies reached an agreement with the nation's attorney general to settle lawsuits filed against these companies. The tobacco companies agreed to allow strict federal regulation of cigarettes, to pay more than three hundred billion dollars for tobacco-related health costs, and to pay additional penalties if youth smoking does not decline. In return the tobacco companies will be protected from certain types of lawsuits and punitive damages. Based on this information, do you favor or oppose the settlement in the tobacco company lawsuit?

source: World Wildlife Fund National Survey, September 1997
question: With whom do you agree more? A. Some/Other people say that most scientist agree that global warming is real and already happening. They say the only scientists who do not believe global warming is happening are paid by big oil, coal and gasoline companies to find the results that will protect business interests, just like the tobacco industry scientists who said cigarettes don't cause cancer. They say there is no real evidence that carbon dioxide emissions from coal, oil and gasoline are causing global warming. With whom do you agree more, those who say global warming is happening or those who say global warming is not happening? (If answer given, ask:)Do you agree strongly or not so strongly?

question: As you may know, negotiations are taking place between tobacco companies and state attorney generals who are suing tobacco companies for the medical costs of treating residents who have experienced tobacco-related illnesses. While some details remain to be worked out, the proposed settlement would call for tobacco companies to give money to the states for compensatory damage, restrict some of its advertising, and take actions to reduce under-age smoking. The states, in turn, would place limitations on the tobacco companies' future legal liabilities. Which do you generally favor...a negotiated settlement between tobacco companies and state attorney generals, or no settlement and allowing damage suits to continue?

question: There have been proposals by the attorney generals in many states to reach an agreement with tobacco companies to settle lawsuits filed against these corporations by smokers and by the states in order to pay the costs of smoking related cases. Statement B: The settlement is a bad idea, because it will prevent future lawsuits against tobacco companies in which individuals could sue and receive damages for smoking-related cases.

topic: HEALTH REGULATION BUSINESS GOVERNMENT STATES COURTS
question: As you may know, tobacco companies and the states that have sued them are talking about a blanket settlement of all smoking-related lawsuits. It would protect the tobacco companies from all future lawsuits--no one else could sue them for damages caused by smoking. In exchange, the tobacco companies would pay up to 300 billion dollars into a fund to pay damages, and would accept more government regulation of cigarettes and more limits on cigarette advertising. Would you support or oppose this settlement?

description:
DOWNLOAD DATASET
Survey by American Cancer Society.
Methodology: Conducted by Marttila & Kiley, April 14 - April 19, 1993 and based on   1,001 telephone interviews. Sample: National registered voters (see note). An additional 442 registered voters who voted in the 1992 Presidential election including oversamples of 157 African-American voters, 99 Hispanic voters, and 186 voters with incomes under $20,000 a year were interviewed by telephone April 20-23, 1993 and April 25, 1993. question: Regardless of whether you happen to be a smoker or not, which of these two opinions do you agree with more:...While protecting the health of nonsmokers, the government should also respect the desire of individuals to smoke, and should try to strike a balance between the concerns of smokers and nonsmokers in creating smoking laws. source: Cambridge Reports National Omnibus Survey, January 1979
question: Of all of these measures, which one do you think would actually do the most to give this country the kind of health care system you want to see?)...01. Government price controls and regulations on what doctors and hospitals could charge 02. Controls to prevent the construction of new hospitals in areas where they are not needed 03. More government and private programs to encourage people to stay healthy, such as anti-smoking campaigns 04. Closing inefficient hospitals or merging them into more efficient units when they are in the same vicinity 05. Government controls on the number of doctors who could enter particular specialities, like surgery, for example 06. Encouraging doctors to advertise and compete on prices for their services 07. Giving insurance companies more power to negotiate fees with doctors and hospitals 08. A health care system with the government owning hospitals and clinics and paying all doctors directly 09. Having patients pay a part of all medical bills even when insurance pays most, so that people will have an incentive to keep costs down and avoid unnecessary treatment
